title: APPLICATION_STATE view | Snowflake Documentation
paragraphs:
The Snowflake Native App Framework is generally available on supported cloud platforms. For additional information, see
Support for private connectivity, VPS, and government regions.

This view in the DATA_SHARING_USAGE schema can be used to display information about apps installed
from a listing for all application packages in the current account.

If a listing was published using
Cross-Cloud Auto-Fulfillment,
this view displays information for installed apps across all regions.
The Snowflake region of the consumer account where the app is installed.
The organization name of the consumer account.
The Snowflake region of the provider account that created the application package.

The current name for the application package in the provider’s account from which the
app was installed.

The hash string of the name of the installed app instance in the consumer account. The consumer uses the
SHA1 function to calculate the hash value of the installed application. The consumer can then
use this value when contacting the provider.
The timestamp when the app instance was first installed.
The current version of the app.
The current patch level of the app.
The timestamp when the current version of the app was installed.
The state of the previous version. Possible values are COMPLETE and FINALIZING.

COMPLETE indicates that upgrade is completed and that there are no active
queries being executed from the previous version, if it exists.

FINALIZING  indicates that the instance has been upgraded from the previous version,
however one or more queries may be still be running that are using the previous version.
The previous version of the app.
The previous patch level of the app.
The version upgrade state of the app. Possible values are:
INSTALLING: The application object is in the process of being created.

INSTALL_FAILED: The creation of the application object failed. The application object
remains in the INSTALL_FAILED state until it is dropped. See the UPGRADE_FAILURE_REASON
column of the DESCRIBE APPLICATION command for information about why the
installation or upgrade failed.

COMPLETE: The setup script successfully completed and the application object was created
or upgraded.
QUEUED: The application object is queued for upgrade.
UPGRADING: The application object is in the process of being upgraded.

FAILED: All upgrade attempts failed. The reason for the failure is listed in the
UPGRADE_FAILURE_REASON column, if present. The instance remains in the FAILED state until
a release directive is updated to point to a different version than the one that the upgrade was
targeting, as defined in the TARGET_UPGRADE_VERSION column.

QUEUED_RETRY: The instance failed one or more upgrade attempts. The reason for the failure
is indicated in UPGRADE_FAILURE_REASON: The instance is queued to perform another upgrade attempt.

DISABLED: The application object and its upgrades were disabled. In this state the instance will be
inaccessible for consumers, it will not be considered for upgrades and will not block application package
version drop. The reason for the failure is listed in the UPGRADE_FAILURE_REASON column, if present.
The target version of the app that is running or pending upgrade.
The version patch level of the app that is running or pending upgrade.
The timestamp when the app upgrade started.
The number of attempts to upgrade to the target version or patch.
The timestamp when the most recent upgrade attempt was attempted.
A description of the failure if the previous app upgrade failed.
The name of the listing on the data exchange from which the app was installed.
The display name of the listing.
The data exchange name of the listing from which the app was installed.
The last reported health status of the app. Possible values are:
The timestamp when the health status was last reported.

A list of event definitions that the consumer has enabled. See
About event definitions
for more information.

The timestamp when the app entered its current upgrade state. This value is automatically set by
Snowflake.
An array containing the reasons why the Snowflake Native App was disabled. See Reasons an app can become disabled.
The following table lists the possible values for the DISABLEMENT_REASONS column:
The app is disabled by Snowflake
Yes. To re-enable the app, contact Snowflake Support.

The account becomes inactive by being locked or suspended causing the app to be unavailable.
In this state a consumer cannot execute any SQL queries in their account and the app cannot be upgraded.
Yes. The app is automatically re-enabled if the account lock or suspension is removed

The application package version for the app was dropped by the provider. The app is no longer usable
and must be dropped and reinstalled from a valid listing or application package

The consumer manages the encryption key themselves (ENCRYPT_USE_CMK_KMS is enabled) and
Snowflake doesn’t have access to this key.

Yes. To re-enable the app, ensure that the cloud provider configuration to retrieve the CMK is correct
and that Snowflake has access to the key.
The listing used to create the app is no longer available. Possible reasons for this status include:
The provider manually removed access to the private listing from the consumer account
Possibly. Recoverability depends on the reason why access was revoked.

For example, if the listing was deleted it is not recoverable. If a consumer account was
manually removed from the private listing, access to the listing and app can be restored.
The application has exceeded the usage limit for a usage-based trial listing.

The listing used to install the app is a paid listing and requires payment for further
usage.
Yes. The consumer must correctly set up payment for the app.
The application exceeded the trial duration.

The application package used to create the app no longer exists. The provider may have
dropped the corresponding application package.
The application package used to create the app is disabled by the Snowflake.
Yes. The app is re-enabled, if Snowflake re-enables the application package.

The app resources for example, tasks, services, and compute pools, are suspended due to
the app being disabled.

The suspended objects remain suspended until the app is re-enabled and there are no other
reasons the app was disabled.
The app resources, for example tasks, services, and compute pools, are currently resuming.

There is no data retention for this view. If an app is uninstalled the information
contained in this view is no longer available.
